awd_titl_txt: A Continuous Coaching Model for High School Computer Science Teachers
awd_abstract_narration:
The United States will need more than 30,000 high school teachers qualified to teach computer science by 2025. While Florida’s Escambia County school district has recently been ramping up efforts to prepare high school teachers in the state, there is a critical need for teacher professional development opportunities. This partnership between University of West Florida, Escambia County School District (ECSD) and Florida’s Department of Education will develop ongoing support and training for current teachers such that they can successfully teach the Advanced Placement Computer Science Principles course, which has been shown to increase student interest and engagement in computing. Though a model of continuous coaching, this partnership will create a cohort of teachers prepared to teach the AP course. At the same time, the team will work with school guidance counselors on strategies to recruit and support students in computing classes, with the goal of increasing the number of students who enroll and are successful in computing classes.  

This proposal will explore a continuous support coaching model, based on Knight’s instructional coaching model, for increasing the pool of future educators without deep pre-existing content knowledge, who will be prepared to coach and teach AP Computer Science Principles (AP-CSP). The coaching model, offered by the University of West Florida’s computer science faculty, will be focused on the pedagogy of computer science, implemented using a constructivist pedagogical approach. The three areas of focus of the coaching model will include: (i) teaching assistance and feedback; (ii) just-in-time assistance offered by coaches; and (iii) lesson modeling. These new coaches and teachers, selected from in-service Math and Science teachers, will be catalysts for broadening participation of computing in Florida high schools, some of which do not yet offer a computing course, and increasing the pass-rates in AP CSP. The project aims to recruit four new coaches, seven new teachers, and seven school guidance counselors to be supported and trained by the program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this grant was to introduce AP Computer Science Principles (CSP) in Escambia County, in the panhandle of Florida. Before we started the grant, AP CSP was not offered in any of the High Schools in Escambia County, except Pensacola High School (PHS). But, PHS did not offer it on a regular basis either.

In order to offer AP CSP successfully in Escambia County, a lot more would have to be done then just providing Professional Development (PD) to teachers. First, the culture of computing had to be introduced. For this we provided PD to the High School Counselors. We talked to them about the importance of Computer Science, so that they could relay this information to potential students. Second, of course, PD was provided to the teachers. We also trained two coaches. In the last year we realized that we needed to have a dialog with the Assistant Principals of the High Schools, so that they too would understand the importance of teaching AP CSP, or, for that matter, any computing course in general. Hence a relationship was built with the Escambia County School District. The Superintendent was also very supportive. A relationship was also built at the state level. In summary, from this grant, 10 counselors and 10 teachers were trained and we worked with 5 Assistant Principals.

Another culture that resulted from our grant was the development of communication between the teachers, high school counselors and Assistant Principals. Since we had a few meetings with all groups together, all the groups, that is, the teachers, counselors, as well as Assistant Principals, got to know each other. This helped in the coordination and student recruitment effort. Assessment results showed that all groups appreciated this aspect of the project.

As a result of our efforts, enrollment has increased dramatically, compared to what it was prior to the grant. Most high schools (six out of the seven high schools in Escambia County) are offering at least one section of AP CSP on a regular basis for the last two years. A total of 333 students have taken AP CSP in the past two years and 112 students are enrolled this year (2024-25). In summary, a total of 445 students have taken/are taking AP CSP as a result of this grant. Females were close to 50% of the enrollment in 2022 and 2023. The pass-rates went up from 0.00% in in 2021 and 2022 (before the award) to 46.63% in 2023 (first year after the award) to 57.74% in 2024.

 Assessment Results

Teachers/coaches appreciated:

● Learning new skills, expanding knowledge, and networking

● Working with other teachers and learning from them

● Getting ideas from university faculty

● That this project opened the door for more students to learn Computer Science Principles

● Open discussion and possibility for teacher PD

Guidance counselors appreciated:

● Learning about AP programs and how to promote AP

Assistant Principals appreciated:

● Learning from other schools and how they are running their CSP

All three groups reported:

●  Liked collaboration between UWF faculty, teachers, counselors, and Assistant Principals

● Loved being able to communicate with peers from other schools

● Flexibility of meetings (online and face-to-face)

Assessment results reported challenges as:

● A limited pool of students at the high schools who are capable of doing the work required

● Students were initially scared of the curriculum and unfamiliar with material

● Recruiting students, making them interested, and having them stay in the CSP

● Encouraging minority students to enroll in AP based courses

● Lack of teachers

Publications resulting from this grant:

1. Bagui, S., Eddy, B., Thompson, C., & Nguyen, G.N. (2023). Generating Interest in Foundational Computer Science in High Schools: A Northwest Florida Case Study, International Journal of Engineering, Science and Technology (IJONEST), 4(4), 254-268. DOI: https://doi.org/10.46328/ijonest.92

2. Cameron, S., Pham, T. and Bagui, S. (2024). A Case Study of Taking AP Computer Science Principles: A Student’s Perspective. Proceedings of the 55th ACM Technical Symposium on Computer Science Education (SIGCSE ’24), March 20-23, Portland, OR. https://doi.org/10.1145/3626253.3635490

Presentations made:

1. Bagui, S. Eddy, B., Thompson, C., Nguyen, G.N. (2022). State of Computer Science Education in High Schools in Northwest Florida, International Conference on Engineering, Science and Technology (Icon EST), Austin, Texas, October 13-16.

2. Bagui, S. State of Computer Science Education in the United States, 2nd Computer Science and Information Technology Virtual, (V-CSIT), UK, February 24, 2023. (Keynote).

3. Bagui, S., (2023). Exploring Computing, Middle School Engineering Workshop, Pensacola High School, Pensacola, FL, July 13, 2023.

4. Cameron, S., Pham, T. and Bagui, S. (2024). A Case Study of Taking AP Computer Science Principles: A Student’s Perspective. 2024 Special Interest Group Computer Science Education (SIGCSE ’24), March 20-23, Portland, OR. https://doi.org/10.1145/3626253.3635490

 


Last Modified: 11/16/2024
Modified by: Sikha S Bagui
